case_title: MUHAMMAD KHAN vs GOVERNMENT OF WEST PAKISTAN AND OTHERS

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Khan
allegation: Failure to pay sale price of auctioned agricultural land

complaint_summary: Muhammad Khan filed a suit for possession of agricultural land measuring 461 kanals and 4 marlas, claiming he was wrongfully dispossessed after failing to pay the auction price and subsequent installments.
investigation_summary: The petitioner purchased state agricultural land between 1951 and 1954 but failed to pay the sale price as per auction terms. The Collector resumed the land and re-auctioned it to other respondents, forfeiting Rs. 10,000 deposited by the petitioner.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the petitioner's suit, holding that the Collector acted within his authority to resume and re-auction the land due to non-payment. The review application was also rejected, as no sufficient grounds for review were found.
legal_arguments: Error apparent on the face of the record regarding Provincial Government's written statement
No notice required before resumption and re-auction under auction terms
Petitioner deemed tenant under sections 10 and 15 of the Colonization of Government Lands Act
assets: 461 kanals and 4 marlas of agricultural land
key_issues: Collector's authority to resume and re-auction land
Applicability of tenant rights under Colonization of Government Lands Act

maxims.Ejusdem Generis: Applied to interpret 'sufficient reason' in review provisions.

legal_terms.Review: A judicial re-examination of the case under Order XLVII, Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
legal_terms.Revision: A supervisory jurisdiction exercised under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

words_and_phrases.Error apparent on the face of the record: A mistake visible without detailed examination.
words_and_phrases.Tenant of State land: A legal status under the Colonization of Government Lands Act.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the petitioner's failure to comply with auction terms for agricultural land, leading to its resumption and re-auction by the Collector. The court upheld the Collector's authority and dismissed the petitioner's suit and subsequent review application.
